question.title: Why would Spring generate a new CSRF during processing of a POST
question.body:
I have a Spring app with form-based authentication and a Restcontroller for my API. I am using Spring Boot 3.5.4 and Spring Security 6. If CSRF is disabled in the security configuration, everything works fine. With CSRF enabled, I can authenticate fine, The GETs work for my API when I pass in the JSESSIONID cookie (csrf token not required for GET). But the POST API call is failing with a 403 Access denied. I've added debug code and found that the csrfilter has an expected token that does not match the token that was passed in the request. I fetch the token(csrf token changes each request) before I make the POST call, which is the same process I used before calling login. Here is my security chain and customauthenticationhandler(to add XSRF-TOKEN to successful authentication response):

"@"Bean
public SecurityFilterChain securityFilterChain(HttpSecurity http) throws Exception {

u/Bean
public AuthenticationSuccessHandler customAuthenticationSuccessHandler() {
    return (request, response, authentication) -> {
        // Retrieve the CSRF token that was generated and stored in the new session/cookie
        System.out.println("CustomAuthenticationSuccessHandler");
        CsrfToken csrfToken = (CsrfToken) request.getAttribute(CsrfToken.class.getName());

        if (csrfToken != null) {
            // Set the token in the response header so the client can access it
            response.setHeader(csrfToken.getHeaderName(), csrfToken.getToken());
        }

        // Continue with default behavior (e.g., redirecting to the original URL)
        new SavedRequestAwareAuthenticationSuccessHandler().onAuthenticationSuccess(request, response, authentication);
    };
}

http
        .exceptionHandling(exceptionHandling -> exceptionHandling
        .accessDeniedHandler(accessDeniedHandler()))

        // Force Csrf token into header
        .csrf(csrf -> csrf
           .csrfTokenRepository(CookieCsrfTokenRepository.withHttpOnlyFalse())
           .csrfTokenRequestHandler(new CsrfTokenRequestAttributeHandler()))

        .addFilterAfter(new CsrfLoggerFilter(), CsrfFilter.class)
        .authorizeHttpRequests((requests) -> requests
        .requestMatchers("/","/index").permitAll()
        .anyRequest().authenticated()
        )
        .formLogin((form) -> form
                .successHandler(customAuthenticationSuccessHandler())
                .loginPage("/login")
                .permitAll()
        )
        .logout((logout) -> logout.permitAll()
        );
return http.build();
}
